title: 107_s1583
content:
The "Travel and Tourism Promotion Act of 2001" includes a provision for a Consumer Travel Tax Credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Travel and Tourism Promotion Act of 2001" includes a provision for a Consumer Travel Tax Credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit allows individuals to claim qualified consumer travel expenses up to $500 ($1000 for joint returns) for travel and lodging expenses related to qualifying personal trips. The Consumer Travel Tax Credit allows individuals to claim up to $500 ($1000 for joint returns) for qualified consumer travel expenses, including lodging at commercial facilities. Qualifying personal trips are defined as leisure travel within the United States between October 1, 2001, and January 1, 2003, excluding expenses for meals, entertainment, amusement, or recreation. The term 'commercial lodging facility' includes hotels, motels, resorts, rooming houses, and campgrounds. Special rules include denying credit to dependents and requiring expenses to be substantiated. The taxpayer must provide a statement of expenses for deduction purposes, and no double benefit is allowed. There are also conforming amendments to related sections in the Internal Revenue Code. TITLE II--TRAVEL AND TOURISM PROMOTION BUREAU

SEC. 21. UNITED STATES TRAVEL AND TOURISM PROMOTION BUREAU. Effective Date: Amendments apply to amounts paid after enactment of this Act, before January 1, 2003. The United States Travel and Tourism Promotion Bureau is established in the Department of Commerce to restore consumer confidence in travel post-9/11 attacks. It collaborates with private industry to promote tourism through public service announcements and advertising. The Bureau has the power to distribute funds and enter contracts with travel-related organizations. The United States Travel and Tourism Promotion Bureau, established in the Department of Commerce post-9/11 attacks, collaborates with private industry to promote tourism. It has the power to enter contracts with private organizations, utilize existing Department of Commerce employees, and conduct necessary acts to achieve its goals. The United States Travel and Tourism Promotion Bureau Advisory Committee is established under SEC. 22. The United States Travel and Tourism Promotion Bureau Advisory Committee (referred to as the Advisory Committee) is established to recommend activities to the Bureau. The Secretary of Commerce appoints members representing various sectors such as aviation, airlines, hotels, restaurant industry, and amusement parks. The Advisory Committee for the United States Travel and Tourism Promotion Bureau includes members from sectors like aviation, airlines, hotels, restaurants, and amusement parks. The committee elects a Chair for a 6-month term and fills vacancies as needed to maintain membership consistency. The Bureau must report quarterly to Senate and House committees on travel and tourism activities and industry status. The provisions of this title will end 2 years after the Act's enactment. SEC. 25. APPROPRIATIONS. Not less than $60,000,000 from the 2001 Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act shall be available for this title. The funds will remain available until September 31, 2003.
